Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Change IItemRendererOwner’s updateRenderer() method definition to:
*  Updates the renderer for re-use. This first prepares the item
*  renderer for re-use by clearing out any stale properties
*  as well as updating it with new properties.

*

The last thing this method should do is set the data property
*  @param itemIndex The index of the data in the data provider
*  @param data The data object this item renderer is representing
Before, it only took one parameter, the renderer.  Now it takes 3.

The reason for this change is to make the code a little cleaner in terms of the separation between DataGroup and List.  Now DataGroup won’t do any work if the mx_internal _rendererUpdateDelegate is set.  If it is set (to a List for instance), then _rendererUpdateDelegate.updateRenderer(renderer, itemIndex, data) will be called.  This makes the updateRenderer() pass more clear because it’s all done in the rendererUpdateDelegate (rather than splitting it in DataGroup and ListBase).  It also makes it easier to get the ordering of properties correctly as we want the “data” property to be the last set property as part of the “item renderer contract”.

As part of this change, DataGroup is the default _rendererUpdateDelegate, and because of this it now implements IItemRendererOwner.  The only other method on IItemRendererOwner besides updateRenderer() is itemToLabel().  DataGroup already had a private itemToLabel() method, so I’m just making it public.
Also, I'm making label and itemIndex bindable to the "dataChange" event now.
QE notes: Please test that the data property is the last thing set
Doc notes: You could update the documentation around item renderers to mention that the data property should be the last thing set.
Tests run: checkintest, mustella list, listdragdrop, dropdownlist, combobox, buttonbar

Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository

We now use the bottleneck method, updateRenderer() to let the DataGroup have first crack at setting a renderer's data, owner and labelText properties. Then the "true" owners like a List or ButtonBar which father a renderer, get a chance to come in and clean out stale properties and set new properties on the renderer (which was either created anew or recycled).
I also cleaned up some comments in LayoutBase.
Mustella: Steve and Ella ok'ed a cyclone I gave them against List, ButtonBar, DataGroup and SkinnableDataContainer.
